Posts.Content: My daVinci surgery (2/24) went well and it looks like they got all of the cancer, Great news there. But it looks like I got a junk transplant from Shaquille O'Neal. My balls are huge and black. Softball size. Is this normal? Gary
Posts.Signature: 61 yrs old. 11-12/14- PSA levels 4.1, 4.8. DRE normal. Prostate biopsy on 1/16 with results on 1/29/15. 4 cores of cancer on right side ([email protected]%, [email protected]%, [email protected]% with perineural invasion present, [email protected]%), 1 core of cancer on left side ([email protected]%) with benign tissue in-between sides. Gleason score of 7 (4+3). Prostatectomy surgery with daVinci scheduled for 2/24/15. Nerve sparing will be attempted on left side only.
Posts.Title: Did they perform a junk transplant?

Posts.Content: I'm going in tomorrow morning for my daVinci surgery. Which of my vehicle choices would be the easiest for me to come home in? 2015 Mazda 3 This is my wife's car and the one she'd prefer to drive. I have to sit low and back in, then swing my legs around to get in. 2005 Ford F250 Lariat Diesel My truck. I would have to step up on the running board then another step up to get into the cab. My wife hasn't driven it and it intimidates her but it has adjustable peddles and seats so she could drive it. 2006 PT Cruiser My son's car. Similar to my wife's car, but not as low to get into. So would it be easier to squat or step up after surgery? Thanks in advance- Gary

Posts.Title: Post-op vehicle choice?

Posts.Content: I'm scheduled for daVinci prostatectomy on 2/24. My surgeon said he would only spare the nerves on the one side which had 1 core 4+3 at 10%. The other side has 4 cores, some at 95%, which I assumed was why he didn't want to spare those. I've been reading that a few guys here had nerve sparing surgeries with all 12 cores showing positive, which now makes me question what the criteria might be in determining whether to remove or leave a nerve bundle behind. Can anyone weigh in on this? Thanks, Gary
Posts.Signature: 61 yrs old. 11-12/14- PSA levels 4.1, 4.8. DRE normal. Posts.Title: A little confused about nerve sparing. What is the criteria?

Posts.Content: Thanks, guys. I agree with the order of priorities of life, continence, and erections. But I will still question the whys and wherefores to confirm I've made the decision that is best for my situation, probably until the day before my surgery. Then whatever happens, happens. Gary

Posts.Title: A little confused about nerve sparing. What is the criteria?

Posts.Content: So we met with Dr. Hettinger, our first possible surgeon yesterday. He is the younger and less experienced of the two that we decided to meet, having done "hundreds" as opposed to Dr. Emmott that is my age (61) and has done over 1000. Both happen to be with the same urology group as Dr. Bock, the urologist that did my biopsies. Besides age and experience, they seem to disagree on the use of the Rocco stitch on the bladder. Dr. Hettinger said he doesn't think it's necessary as he has had the same continence success without it and avoids stitching into healthy tissue or organs whenever possible. He said that there is a remote chance the bladder could actually rupture which really sounds no bueno. We meet with Dr. Emmott tomorrow and we'll go over why he uses it, but I would love to hear input from you guys first, if possible. Meanwhile- My beautiful and incredibly supportive wife (52) now has to have her uterus biopsied next week because of some raised suspicions and just to keep things interesting, we learned this morning that her mammogram shows calcium grains which could possibly be yet another early warning sign of cancer. I beginning to wonder if our house was built over native burial grounds or a toxic dump. God, if you really feel the need to smack someone, please consider ISIS. They like martyrdom. Gary
Posts.Title: To Rocco, or not to Rocco. That is the question.

Posts.Content: Thank you guys. Knowledge is power. My wife has already printed out the "Questions to Ask My Doctor" form from the American Cancer Society website and has networked the name of a recommended oncologist for another opinion. My urologist did a good job on my vasectomy 5 years ago but I know this is a different ball game (rimshot!). I'm not far from the University of Kansas (KU) Medical Center. I'll have to check them out as well. I read on another thread where someone recommended getting a second pathology opinion from John Hopkins. Would my lab have kept the 12 samples to be able to do this? Is it even necessary given my lab results? Wilde- You had your surgery rather quickly, with what seems to me a better lab result than I got. How did that go? Our appointment is for 11:15 this morning. We'll see what he says. Gary
Posts.Title: New guy. Just a week ago, I thought male pattern baldness was my main aging concern.

Posts.Content: Hello from Kansas City. Wow. I am still in a bit of shock and my brain is trying to process everything I've been reading since being diagnosed with PC last Thursday. It's an unwanted early birthday present as I will turn 61 on 1/31. I'm sure I'll have questions to post later, but first I wanted to introduce myself and post what I know as of now. There has been no known history of prostate cancer in my family. That could be because most died young (under 70) of other cancers, mostly lung. My dad was 59. I grew up athletic and I've stayed pretty active. I do reenacting as a captain of a Union civil war cavalry company hence the "FedCav". My DRE was normal but my PSA came back 4.1 last November. Two weeks later it was 4.8 so to "play it safe" a biopsy was scheduled for 1/16. it came back as 4+3=7 with cancer in both halves of the prostate and a perineural invasion present. My wife (together since 1984 and still going strong) and I are having our first "treatment options" meeting with my urologist tomorrow. Here are my lab results: Right medial base: ￼￼￼- Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 involving 75% of core. 2. Right medial mid: - Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 involving 95% of core. 3. Right medial apex - Focal atypical small acinar proliferation. 4. Right lateral base: - Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7 involving 95% of core. - Perineural invasion present. 5. Right lateral mid: - Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 involving 20% of core. 6. Right lateral apex: - Benign prostate tissue 7. Left medial base: - Benign prostate tissue. 8. Left medial mid: - Benign prostate tissue. 9. Left medial apex: - Benign prostate tissue. 10. Left lateral base: - High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. 11. Left lateral mid: - High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. 12. Left lateral apex: - Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+3=7 involving 10% of core. Well, here I am. I'll report back after our meeting tomorrow. Thanks for being here. Gary
Posts.Title: New guy. Just a week ago, I thought male pattern baldness was my main aging concern.

Posts.Content: From ddayglo: An old man went to the Doctor. The Doctor said "I'm sorry, but I'll need a urine sample, a stool sample, and a semen sample" The old man said "I'll make it easy for you Doc. Just take my underwear."
Posts.Title: Two blondes walk into a hospital...

Posts.Content: You'd think one of them would have seen it. According to Reader's Digest, "Laughter is the Best Medicine". If it's okay with the moderators, I thought it might be good to have a humor thread to help keep our spirits up. If you add a joke, please keep it somewhat clean so no one gets offended. Think PG-13 and avoid vulgarity. If you tend to get offended easily, then don't continue reading this thread.
Posts.Title: Two blondes walk into a hospital...

Posts.Content: Two old men greet each other at a yearly reunion. One asks the other why he seems so happy. "Oh, I had a great night of love making last night. We did it three times!". "What?" his friend replies. "How is that possible?". "I had a penis transplant. Works like a teenager's. Best decision of my life." "Really? If you're serious, I want the name of that doctor." So he gives him the name and wishes him luck. The next year they see each again and he discreetly asks if he went ahead with the transplant. "Yeah, but I'm not at all happy with it. It only gets hard for a minute or two, then it's like pushing a rope uphill. It's small and has this really weird curve to the left." "What?!! Meet me in the men's room, I've got to see this." So they meet there and he shows his friend his unhappy results. "Oh, I was afraid of that. Bad news, buddy." "What? What's going on?" He sighs, puts his hand on his friends shoulder and whispers "I think you got my trade in.".
Posts.Title: Two blondes walk into a hospital...

Posts.Content: Chuck- I've decided on surgery with the doctor who has performed 1000+.
Posts.Title: Decided on a doctor and scheduling for daVinci.

Posts.Content: Three old men are sitting together on a park bench. The first one says, "You know, it's been five years since I've had a good crap." The second one replies, "That's nothing. It's been 20 years since I had a good pee." The third one says, "I must be blessed. Every morning at 6 am I have a good pee. Every morning at 7am, I have a good crap. Now, if I could just wake up before 8am…"
Posts.Title: Two blondes walk into a hospital...

Posts.Content: We met with the radiologist today and she too recommends surgery, because of my age (61) and general good health. Should the surgery not get it all, which is unlikely, then we can do radiation. Although I am a good candidate for either, they say surgery after radiation is very difficult and not too many doctors attempt it. Kind of a no brainer, then. We are going with Dr. David F. Emmott. He is the older surgeon (61) of the two we met, with the thousand plus daVinci surgeries under his belt. His explanation of why he does the Rocco stitch made sense. He said I was the first patient to ever ask him about the Rocco stitch, which is a credit to the information available on this site. He only schedules himself for one surgery a day, which is great. He was very sincere, pleasant and brutally honest about my somewhat slim chances of getting natural erections. He will not spare the nerves on the right side as he feels there is too much risk in leaving some cancer behind. He will try to spare the left side nerves, however. Better limp in life than stiff in death, right? For those who are following along, my wife is getting her uterus biopsied on Monday and her breasts biopsied on Tuesday. Positive thoughts that both her pathology reports come back negative are appreciated. Hell of a week we've had. Gary
Posts.Title: Decided on a doctor and scheduling for daVinci.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ray61 Sounds like we are both on a similar path. I hope you don't mind if I steal your " Better limp in life than stiff in death" quote. Good thoughts go out to your wife and you. keep us informed on progress. Ray Ray- Mi limp es su limp. Our lives can sure change in a heartbeat, huh? Good luck to us both. Captain Limpy
